poem:
### Playmobil Dreams

In tiny plastic grandeur, the child commands,  
a mansion mocked by scrutinizing hands.  
Miniatures dwell where ghosts of mould once stayed,  
a porridge bowl, outsized fridge, hopes replayed.

In dreams, a home returns with open gates,  
to haunt the brave who weathered paper fates.  
Toy bricks and pastel walls, reality mislaid.

Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
